results.title: Leave no man behind
results.creator_credit: Les Maher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Even though Les Maher believed you should never leave a man behind, there was a time in Vietnam that he had to make the decision to do so. Decades later, Maher has never forgotten and endeavoured to fulfil his promise.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Les Maher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Sink or swim
results.creator_credit: Gwynneth Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Gwynneth Cole joined the army in 1944, roles for women were limited. While Cole didn’t get to serve on the front line, she was posted to different bases in Australia as a nurse and faced many hardships and the realities of war. Cole greatly values her time in the army and reflects on the opportunities for women and the independent streak she has passed on to her four daughters.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gwynneth Cole, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: When Gwynneth Cole joined the army in 1944, roles for women were limited. Cole greatly values her time in the army and reflects on the opportunities for women and the independent streak she has passed on to her four daughters.

results.title: The Knock at the door
results.creator_credit: Helen Raw, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: War has followed Helen all her life. As a young girl, she wrote letters to her brothers overseas and she had feared losing her husband in the Vietnam war. That dreaded knock on the door was something she never wanted to hear.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Helen Raw, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Fishing on the Diamantina
results.creator_credit: Wayne Gwynne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Wayne Gwynne joined the Navy in 1960 when he was 17. Spending 5 years at sea, during peacetime, Gwynne got to see things that no one has seen before. While he still can’t talk about those things, he loved his time at sea, especially on his favourite ship, the ‘Diamantina’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wayne Gwynne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Wayne Gwynne joined the Navy in 1960 when he was 17. Spending 5 years at sea, during peacetime, Gwynne got to see things that no one has seen before. While he still can’t talk about those things, he loved his time at sea, especially on his favourite ship, the ‘Diamantina’.

results.title: A Boy called "Rabbit"
results.creator_credit: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Cumming’s dearest memory of the time he served in Vietnam was a young boy by the name of “Rabbit”. While “Rabbit” couldn’t speak English, he was popular with the Australian soldiers for his fast running and bravery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: A Secret war room
results.creator_credit: Joan Peck, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Joan Peck served in the WAAAF as a radio telephone operator at Number one fighter sector in Preston. Their main role was to connect the army, navy and airforce in one central control to help protect and defend the Victorian coastline. Peck used state of the art technology at work, yet didn’t even have a telephone at home. Her highly secretive and crucial work at the centre was often interspersed with a spot of knitting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Peck, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Joan Peck served in the WAAAF as a radio telephone operator at Number one fighter sector in Preston. Their main role was to connect the army, navy and airforce in one central control to help protect and defend the Victorian coastline. Peck used state of the art technology at work, yet didn’t even have a telephone at home. Her highly secretive and crucial work at the centre was often interspersed with a spot of knitting.

results.title: Every man for himself
results.creator_credit: Arthur Bedford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Hiding from the Germans amongst olive trees in Greece, Arthur Bedford and his fellow soldiers were told to get out. “Every man for himself”. Not only did they manage to escape, they managed to fend off a enemy bombing attack and didn’t suffer a single casualty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arthur Bedford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: The Boy who came in from the cold
results.creator_credit: Jack Darling, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alfred (Jack) Darling was a gunner on the ANZAC during the Korean War. The boys came up with as many ways as possible to overcome the Korean winter, including growing a beard, which required permission from the captain.

results.title: The Battle of Coral
results.creator_credit: Tony Stewart, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Instinct kicked in when Private Tony Stewart and his fellow soldiers were engaged in the Battle for Coral, in Vietnam, 1968. It was the most horrific battle he would take part in but this is what Stewart was trained for and he know he had his mates there to look after him.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Stewart, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Instinct kicked in when Private Tony Stewart and his fellow soldiers were engaged in the Battle for Coral, in Vietnam, 1968. It was the most horrific battle he would take part in but this is what Stewart was trained for and he know he had his mates there to look after him.

results.title: Singapore dollars
results.creator_credit: Edward Dunstan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Edward Dunstan served in the Australian Navy for 20 years, spending a significant part of that time in Singapore. While he enjoyed his time there, Dunstan also has some bad memories, not least of all was how he was received by his fellow Australians on his return. However, these experiences have encouraged him to help others through his work at the RSL.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edward Dunstan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

However, these experiences have encouraged him to help others through his work at the RSL.
description_for_label: Edward Dunstan served in the Australian Navy for 20 years, spending a significant part of that time in Singapore. While he enjoyed his time there, Dunstan also has some bad memories, not least of all was how he was received by his fellow Australians on his return. However, these experiences have encouraged him to help others through his work at the RSL.
